intro: Acaena lucida var. villosula, commonly known as the silky burrplant, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its dense, spiny bracts that enclose the small, yellow flowers. The plant produces spherical, woody fruits that are covered in soft, white hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understoreys. The species is valued for its ornamental qualities and ecological role in supporting native wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena lucida var. villosula is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the southern and western regions of the country. This variety thrives in coastal and lowland areas, often growing in sandy or gravelly soils. It is commonly associated with coastal shrublands and open vegetation. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate and maritime conditions of its native habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena lucida var. villosula was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there during the 19th century as part of the ornamental plant trade. This variety is characterized by its dense, woolly foliage and bright yellow flowers. It has since become naturalized in certain regions, particularly in the North Island. However, it is considered a potential weed in some areas due to its ability to spread rapidly in disturbed soils.
